Award.AwardTitle: Calibrating Diatom Oxygen Isotopes for Paleoceanographic Applications Using a Novel Technique
Award.AbstractNarration:
The oxygen isotopic composition (delta18O) of silicate in diatom tests has the potential to deliver key paleoceanographic information, but is underutilized because of the difficulty associated with isolating it for geochemical analysis. This work will refine and apply a new technique ("microfluorination") that has the potential to make d18O in diatoms a more routine measurement. A suite of experiments will be conducted to improve the efficiency of the technique and reduce the sample size required for analysis. The technique will then be applied to cultured marine and freshwater diatoms in order to calibrate the proxy relationship between diatom delta18O and temperature. Finally, diatoms from a sediment trap and boxcore collected in the Guaymas Basin will be analyzed to a) constrain biomineralization depth, b) compare oxygen isotope data between diatoms and foraminifera, and c) assess diagenetic effects on diatom delta18O data.

Developing the microfluorination technique and the diatom delta18O-temperature proxy relationship will enable scientists to tap an important, underexploited source of information about ocean-climate dynamics. The project will support a PhD student and provide training opportunities in a state-of-the-art technique for undergraduate students and future post-doctoral researchers in the PI's lab. Project results will be incorporated into graduate coursework. This research will strengthen international ties via collaboration with investigators in the UK and Germany.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The oxygen isotope chemistry of the cell walls of diatoms, a type of golden brown algae, is controlled by the temperature and oxygen isotope chemistry of the water they grow in. After diatoms die, their skeletal remains sink to the seafloor and become part of the fossil record. However, the oxygen isotope chemistry of these fossil remains contain an archive of environmental information about the near surface water column when the algae were alive.  It has been difficult to analyze diatom fossil remains because the skeletons are made of silica (SiO2), often called opal. Researchers in the past were required to utilize dangerous caustic chemicals and highly specialized equipment to breakdown the tough opal skeleton for paleoenvironmental studies. This project has focused on the development of a relatively easy analytical method, called microfluorination, to analyze opal SiO2 materials for their oxygen isotope composition. In this project, we develop laboratory techniques for processing samples and improve calibrations used to interpret diatom oxygen isotope data for paleoenvironmental reconstructions of past ocean temperatures.

Our new technique, microfluorination, uses Teflon powder (PTFE type MP1200) and graphite as reagents to break the Si-O covalent bonds in a high temperature furnace (TC/EA) at 1450C. Our laboratory experiments demonstrated that diatom remains are susceptible to alteration as the diatom remains move from the water column to the deep sea sediment. We have also quantified the slow alteration of diatom oxygen isotopes over hundreds of thousands of years as the opal sits in the sediment column. Our results show that these changes occur in a predictable manner. These changes are due to interaction with surrounding bottom water and slow changes in the chemical structure of the opal remains once they become part of the seafloor sediment.

Finally, we demonstrate the practical application of these research experiments by analyzing sediment samples from the Guaymas Basin, Gulf of California, that were deposited during the last two centuries. Our results suggest that the diatoms in this location recorded a warming trend in the upper water column over the last 25 years of the 20th century.
